Award.AwardTitle: Achieving 15% PCE Solution Processed Hybrid Triple-Junction Solar Cells

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Research Objectives and Approaches - The objective of this research is to advance the solution processed hybrid triple-junction photovoltaic technology to 15% efficiency. The approaches are comprehensive and include: design of organic donor and acceptor materials with high efficiency and spectrum-matched absorption; a solution processed inorganic solar cell to cover the near-IR spectrum; novel interlayer and hybrid tandem solar cells; and novel transparent electrodes to realize all solution processed hybrid tandem solar cells. 15% efficiency will be a milestone for low-cost high efficiency solar cells.

Intellectual merit - Renewable energy is crucial for sustainable economic development and environmental protection. The proposed research represents a new front in solar cell research and integrates both chemistry and materials science to generate new perspectives in science and offer solutions to challenging sustainable energy issues. We aim to contribute to our national energy security and a greener economy by achieving a breakthrough in solution processed high efficiency solar cells. This project will not only give us device success, but enrich our understanding of fundamental physics.

Broader impacts - The proposed research will impact the national and global effort in developing new sustainable energy strategies and technologies, thus impact our nation?s economy and improve environmental quality by reducing the use of fossil fuels. This project offers students (from high school to graduate-level) the opportunity to learn the skills to face future scientific challenges. The team has strong partnerships with the private sector through patent licensing, which will continue and greatly benefit the US economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome Report

Intellectual Merit:

This project is to advance the solution processed hybrid organic triple-junction solar cell technology with power conversion efficiency beyond amorphous Si and approaching that of poly-Si solar cells. The centerpiece of our technical approach includes: (1) synthesis novel organic donor and acceptor materials with high PCEs and spectrum-matched absorption; (2) solution processed inorganic CZTS solar cell withr the Near-IR (from 800 nm to 1200 nm) response; (3) optimization of single junction devices based on the materials; (4) develop novel nano-functional interlayer and novel geometry of hybrid tandem solar cells to maximize solar energy conversion; (5) develop solution processed transparent electrodes to realize all solution process hybrid tandem solar cells. The achievements include:

       - Fully Solution-Processed Nanocrystals-Based Cu2ZnSn(S,Se)4 (CZTS) solar cell

We obtained very reproducible solution processed CIGS solar cells with ~8-10% power conversion efficiency (PCE), which is among the state-of-the-art level in this field.

- Highly efficient solution-processed perovskite solar cell

By controlling the formation of the perovskite layer and careful choices of other materials, we achieved the state-of-the-art perovksite solar cell with the highest efficiency of ~19.3% in a planar geometry without antireflective coating. We reported a growth mode for via thermal annealing of the perovskite precursor film in a humid environment (e.g., ambient air) to greatly improve the film quality, grain size, carrier mobility, and lifetime that can pave the way towards efficient photovoltaic conversion.

       - Highly efficient tandem solar cells

Hybrid tandem solar cells based on a-Si and polymer:fullerene bulk heterojunction have been realized. While the two single-junction sub cells have power conversion efficiency in the range of 6~7.5%, the dual junction tandem cell reaches maximum efficiency of 10.5%.

a) We developed new interconnection layer-MoO3 acts as anode contact for the front sub-unit, and ZnO as the cathode for the back cell. Optical management allows nearly complete light harvesting in the spectral range from 350 nm to 800 nm. Therefore 25% efficiency enhancement can be obtained, and power conversion efficiency was improved from 8.0% in the single junction reference cell to 10.2% in the tandem cell.

b) We have reported over 10% power conversion efficiency in amorphous-Si/Low bandgap polymer OPV tandem device.

c) Based on the success of both narrow bandgap perovskite solar cell and low band gap solution processed inorganic solar cell, we successfully demonstrated solution processed perovskite/Cu(In,Ga)(Se,S)2 four terminal tandem solar cells. We develop a multilayer transparent top electrode for perovskite photovoltaic devices delivering an 11.5% efficiency in top illumination mode. A four terminal tandem solar cell employing solution processed CIGS and perovskite cells is also demonstrated with over 15% efficiency.

d) We developed a highly efficient Silicon/Perovskite tandem solar cell. We demonstrated 20.6% efficient perovskite/silicon solar cell, which constitutes over 10% improvement compared to the bottom silicon single junction devices (~18%).

 

Broader Impact:

Under the sponsorship of the NSF funding from October 2012 to September 2016, our group has carried out the training for four graduate students to obtain doctoral degree, including Dr. Letian Dou, Dr. Wei-Hsuan Chang, Dr. Chun-Chao Chen, and Dr. Tze-Bing Song.

Furthermore, four postdoc scholars, Dr. Yongsheng Liu, Dr. Huanping Zhou, Dr. Qi Chen and Dr. Jingbi, You, have been benefited from the sponsorship for their career development. The training provided students and postdoc scholars the fundamental concepts and skills of comprehensive research as well as stimulating their interest in applied scientific research.

The PI has participated NSF workshops on PV in general and on OPV to disseminate the research to broader society.
